props.title: Israeli gunfire kills at least 25 in Gaza as Netanyahu says he will allow Palestinians to leave

props.summary: Hamas' chief negotiator is in talks with Egyptian mediators about a potential ceasefire in the ongoing Gaza war, while Israel continues its military operations, including heavy airstrikes on Gaza City. Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu suggested that Palestinians could leave the enclave, a notion that has drawn international condemnation, likening it to a forced displacement reminiscent of the 1948 Nakba. The humanitarian crisis in Gaza is dire, with reports of widespread starvation and malnutrition affecting the population, as the death toll from the conflict surpasses 60,000, prompting calls for increased aid and a ceasefire.
props.title: Israel says Gazans free to exit while Hamas attends Cairo ceasefire talks

props.summary: Authorities have discovered a body believed to be that of Blake Kieckhafer, a 23-year-old man from Omaha, Nebraska, who went missing after taking a ride share to Rocky Mountain National Park on August 7. The remains were found above Emerald Lake, and search efforts began after his family reported him missing on August 11. The Larimer County Coroner's Office will confirm the identity of the body.
props.title: Authorities Find Body Believed to Be 23-Year-Old Man Who Disappeared After Hailing a Ride to Rocky Mountain National Park

props.summary: Washington, DC Police Chief Pamela Smith has signed an executive order allowing local police to share information with federal immigration enforcement, despite existing prohibitions against inquiring about immigration status. This move comes amid President Trump's federalization of DC's police force and a crackdown on illegal immigration, raising concerns among immigrant communities about safety and local autonomy. Mayor Muriel Bowser, who previously identified DC as a sanctuary city, has shifted her stance, proposing changes to local laws that limit cooperation with federal immigration authorities.
props.title: DC police to share information with federal immigration officers

props.summary: Vladimir Putin's upcoming visit to the U.S. marks a significant moment in U.S.-Russia relations, as he seeks to leverage his strongman image to gain favor with President Trump, who admires him. The meeting is expected to focus on aggressive demands from Putin regarding Ukraine, including territorial concessions and military limitations, while Trump aims to project himself as a capable deal-maker. Observers express concern that the talks may ultimately benefit Putin, especially if they fail to yield a compromise, potentially enhancing his domestic and international standing.
props.title: What Putin says and what he REALLY means are two different things

props.summary: CaliberCos Inc (NASDAQ:CWD) reported a significant reduction in its platform adjusted loss to $54,000 in Q2 2025, down from $2.5 million in Q2 2024, attributed to cost-saving initiatives. The company has entered a development rights agreement with Hyatt to develop 15 new hotels and has seen a 6% increase in managed capital, reaching $498 million. However, it faces challenges such as an impairment charge of $2.3 million and delays in securing construction loans, while a potential lower interest rate environment could improve financing capabilities and enhance performance allocations.
props.title: CaliberCos Inc (CWD) Q2 2025 Earnings Call Highlights: Strategic Partnerships and Cost-Saving ...

props.summary: The Trump administration has intensified its conflict with Harvard University, formally accusing it of tolerating antisemitism, which could threaten its federal funding. A federal task force's investigation found Harvard to be a 'willful participant' in antisemitic harassment, leading to potential civil rights lawsuits if the university does not comply with federal demands. Harvard has strongly disagreed with the findings and maintains its commitment to combatting bias, while the administration has already cut over $2.6 billion in research grants and threatened to revoke the university's tax-exempt status.
props.title: Trump administration threatens to cut all Harvard funding

props.summary: House Republicans are working to finalize a tax and spending bill, facing opposition from the Freedom Caucus over provisions like the SALT deduction and green energy tax credits. The bill's passage is uncertain, with concerns about its impact on the deficit and potential cuts to Medicaid and Medicare. Lawmakers are engaged in negotiations, with President Trump involved in discussions to unify support, while Democrats express strong opposition to the proposed cuts and the overall financial implications of the legislation.
props.title: Freedom Caucus Threatens to Tank Vote

props.summary: Apple’s rumored iPhone 17 Air is slated to feature a 6.6‑inch OLED ProMotion display, a titanium frame, a single 48‑MP rear camera, and an A19‑based chip, with a price around $899.  Early‑adopter concerns echo past first‑run glitches—overheating, battery life, and structural issues—while Apple may mitigate them with a new C1 modem and custom Wi‑Fi.  The device is expected to launch in September 2025, offering a slimmer, premium alternative to the 17 Pro line but potentially sacrificing camera versatility and battery endurance.  Overall, the market will watch for how Apple balances form, performance, and reliability in this new ultra‑thin flagship.
props.title: Why I Won't Be Buying the iPhone 17 Air on Release Day

props.summary: The First Trust Cloud Computing ETF (NASDAQ: SKYY) presents a compelling investment opportunity within the cloud computing sector, although its current rating is influenced by broader market dynamics. The article is authored by an experienced stock analyst with a focus on equity valuation and market trends, emphasizing a data-driven approach to investment research. The analyst discloses no personal financial interests in the companies mentioned, and the article reflects personal opinions rather than formal investment advice.
props.title: SKYY ETF: Fits Between Mega Cap Safety And Growth Risk (NASDAQ:SKYY)

props.summary: From August 8 to 10, 2025, the "China Up Close Series: Zhejiang Tour" hosted nearly 70 journalists and editors from various countries, including South Korea, Spain, Bulgaria, and Iceland, in Deqing, Zhejiang province. The event, organized in collaboration with CGTN, aimed to showcase the region's landscapes, history, and culture to international audiences.
props.title: CCTV+: China Up Close: Zhejiang Tour Explores Deqing

props.summary: The Smithsonian Institution is undergoing a comprehensive review to align its exhibits with President Trump's interpretation of American history, following pressure from the White House. New exhibits include a diorama of Revolutionary War forces and a Civil War display featuring fictional elements, while interactive features aim to present a sanitized version of history. Critics argue this represents a dangerous politicization of historical institutions, while supporters claim it promotes a unifying narrative. The changes are set to be implemented within 120 days, with the Smithsonian emphasizing its commitment to scholarly excellence amidst these alterations.
props.title: Smithsonian's New Trump-Approved History: Revolutionary Airports, Living Abolitionists and More!

props.summary: In Van Nuys, Los Angeles, police arrested Gary Boyadzhayan, a man who had been disturbing his neighborhood with loud train horns attached to a tree in his backyard. Neighbors expressed concern for his well-being, describing the situation as a 'cry for help' amid ongoing complaints about the noise. Boyadzhayan was taken into custody for disturbing the peace and interfering with a peace officer, but was released shortly after. The LAPD is working to address the noise issue while also seeking to provide assistance to Boyadzhayan.
props.title: A man blaring a train alarm torments L.A. neighborhood. Then he was arrested

props.summary: Wildfires across Southern Europe—spanning Spain, Portugal, Greece, Italy, Turkey, and neighboring countries—have intensified amid a severe heat wave, with temperatures exceeding 104°F in many areas. Multiple major blazes have forced thousands to evacuate, closed highways and rail lines, and claimed several lives, while firefighting crews and aircraft are stretched thin. Heat alerts and high fire risk warnings have been issued by national meteorological agencies, and international aid has been mobilized to support overwhelmed local resources. The fires have also highlighted concerns over arson, power line faults, and careless farming practices as contributing factors.
props.title: Spain, Portugal, and Greece battle wildfires as heatwave is expected to last for days

props.summary: The new $250 visa integrity fee, slated to begin in 2026, is expected to deter about 5.4% of international visitors, potentially cutting roughly 1 million trips and $29 billion in tourism revenue, according to tourism economists, while the CBO projects only $2.7 billion in fee revenue because it ignores macroeconomic feedback.  The fee comes amid a broader Trump‑era push that includes a possible expansion of the travel ban to 36 more countries, a $80 million cut to Brand USA’s marketing budget, and heightened scrutiny of U.S. border enforcement—all of which are eroding the country’s appeal to foreign travelers.  These policies threaten to undermine the projected $30.5 billion economic boost from the 2026 FIFA World Cup, as host cities rely on a 50/50 split of domestic and international fans to fill stadiums and hotels.  Overall, the combination of higher fees, stricter bans, and reduced marketing is likely to keep U.S. tourism on a downward trajectory for years to come.
props.title: Controversial $250 Visa Integrity Fee Will Cost US $11 Billion As It Deters Tourists, Analysts Say

props.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump is meeting Russian President Vladimir Putin in Alaska for a high‑stakes summit aimed at ending the Ukraine war and reshaping European security. Trump seeks to position himself as a dealmaker and global peacemaker, while Putin hopes to secure Russia’s gains and block Ukraine’s NATO aspirations. The talks risk legitimizing Putin and sidelining Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, raising concerns about a deal that may not align with Ukraine’s interests. Both leaders face significant domestic and international scrutiny, and the summit’s success remains uncertain as their demands diverge sharply.
props.title: Trump’s meeting with Putin could determine the trajectory of the Russia-Ukraine war

props.summary: Lauren Sanchez Bezos celebrated her wedding to Jeff Bezos and her son Evan’s departure to college, sharing a photo of him setting up his dorm. The couple, who recently moved their primary residence from Seattle to Florida’s Indian Creek Island, are building a new compound while Bezos’s tax savings from the move are estimated at $610 million. Bezos owns several homes on the island, with one set to become their main residence as the others are slated for demolition. The family’s Florida lifestyle is highlighted by proximity to other high-profile neighbors such as Tom Brady and Ivanka Trump.
props.title: Lauren Sanchez Bezos Is Left 'Heartbroken' After Son Evan Moves Out of Family Home To Start 'His Next Chapter' at College

props.summary: UEFA opened a disciplinary case after Maccabi Haifa fans displayed the slogan “Murderers since 1939” at a Conference League match against Rakow Czestochowa, prompting condemnation from the Polish president and Israel’s embassy. The Polish government and Israeli ambassador expressed outrage, and both clubs were charged with transmitting a message not fit for a sports event, with possible fines or stadium closures pending. The incident follows a week‑long clash in which Rakow fans also displayed a banner accusing Israel of murder. UEFA has faced criticism for its own political messaging, having recently shown anti‑violence slogans at high‑profile matches while not sanctioning a PSG banner calling for a stop to Gaza genocide.
props.title: UEFA charges Israeli and Polish clubs over political fan banners that raised diplomatic tension

props.summary: The Indiana Fever (18‑15) and Washington Mystics (14‑18) face a must‑win matchup on Friday, with both teams battling injuries and recent losing streaks. Fever are missing key guard Caitlin Clark and have lost two other guards to season‑ending injuries, while the Mystics are out of the playoff picture after five losses in six games. Fever recently lost 81‑80 to the Dallas Wings after a late comeback, and coach Stephanie White criticized officiating. Mystics have relied on rookie rebound leader Kiki Iriafen and scorer Sonia Citron, but still sit in 10th place. The game will be played at Gainbridge Fieldhouse at 7:30 p.m. ET and is a critical opportunity for both teams to improve their standings.
props.title: Indiana Fever host Washington Mystics on Friday: TV channel, time, how to watch

props.summary: Daryl Hall and John Oates settled their business dispute over the sale of a stake in their joint venture, Whole Oats Enterprises, through arbitration, leading Hall to dismiss his lawsuit without prejudice on August 11. The case had earlier seen a temporary restraining order blocking Oates’ planned sale to Primary Wave Music, pending an arbitrator’s decision. Hall accused Oates of a ‘partnership betrayal’ by attempting to sell without Hall’s written approval, while Oates countered that Hall’s claims were ‘inflammatory and inaccurate.’ The settlement leaves the sale’s outcome unclear, but the parties are no longer in court and may potentially refile the issue later.}
props.title: Daryl Hall and John Oates quietly resolve lawsuit over sale of joint venture. What to know

props.summary: Former "Bachelorette" star Trista Sutter posted an emotional Instagram Reel on Aug. 14 celebrating her daughter Blakeley's first day of junior year and son Maxwell's first day of senior year, reflecting on how quickly time passes. The clip compiled photos from their first days of school each year, ending with a sweet moment of the siblings together. Sutter also shared a pet‑peeve about parents at kids' sports games, insisting they sit on their team’s side, and has previously posted family photos for Easter and other milestones. The article highlights her gratitude for family and her ongoing engagement with fans through social media.
props.title: Trista and Ryan Sutter's 2 Kids Look All Grown Up on the First Day of Junior and Senior Year

props.summary: Vonnie Quinn reports that U.S. consumer sentiment has dipped for the first time since April as inflation expectations climb, prompting a cautious outlook on Fed policy.  Fed officials and market analysts expect a modest 25‑basis‑point rate cut in September, but only if labor market weakness intensifies, while the Fed remains wary of a sharp easing.  Credit markets continue to show a high‑yield supply boom and resilient fundamentals, though investors remain vigilant about potential risks from tariff policy and geopolitical events.  The upcoming Jackson Hole symposium will be pivotal for clarifying the Fed’s stance on inflation and employment.
props.title: Debate Heats Up Over Fed's Next Move

props.summary: Mark Cuban and Rashaun Williams counsel entrepreneurs to prioritize customers, sales, and profitability before seeking external funding, warning that chasing capital without proven demand is a common mistake. Cuban stresses the value of sweat equity, cutting personal expenses, and fully understanding the obligations that come with investment. Williams distills the funding challenge into three barriers—net worth, network, and traction—and recommends early self-funding, leveraging friends, family, angels, or crowdfunding to build traction. Both agree that learning from experienced founders and attending events like the Clover x Shark Tank Summit can be pivotal for building a solid, sustainable business.
props.title: Sharks Mark Cuban and Rashaun Williams Secrets to Raising Capital

props.summary: The article debunks a rumor that the IRS will issue new stimulus checks this summer, explaining that no legislation authorizes such payments and that the IRS has no plans to distribute them. It reviews the history of COVID‑19 stimulus payments, noting that all prior rounds were enacted by Congress and administered by the Treasury and IRS. The piece also details the Recovery Rebate Credit, a refundable credit for taxpayers who missed earlier payments, and explains how the IRS is automatically sending about $2.4 billion to eligible individuals who failed to claim it on their 2021 returns. Finally, it reminds taxpayers that to receive any remaining credit they must file a 2021 return by April 15 2025.
props.title: No, taxpayers will not receive new stimulus checks this summer

props.summary: The speaker discusses the current state of the investment‑grade credit market, noting robust demand across rating levels and a cycle‑type spread environment after a late‑summer supply issue. They highlight that while valuations are tight, idiosyncratic risks are rising, especially in cyclical and tariff‑exposed sectors that haven’t fully benefited from recent recoveries. The speaker advises caution in avoiding weaker sectors while still remaining optimistic about spread expansion, citing firm technicals and solid fundamentals at the peak of the credit cycle.
props.title: Demand Dynamics are Robust: O'Connor

props.summary: The piece previews Dillian Whyte’s upcoming bout against 20‑year‑old prospect Moses Itauma, noting Whyte’s recent knockout losses and the expectation that Itauma could stop him early, with betting odds heavily favoring the younger fighter. It also references Whyte’s rematch with Alexander Povetkin and a potential fight with Tyson Fury, outlining Whyte’s ambition to regain title contention and the contrasting styles and records of each opponent. Overall, the article highlights Whyte’s challenging path against rising talent and seasoned champions, offering odds, predictions, and context for each matchup.
props.title: Moses Itauma Vs. Dillian Whyte: Odds, Records, Prediction

props.summary: Tracee Ellis Ross revealed an awkward TSA moment on Jimmy Kimmel Live when agents opened her carry‑on and found personal bedside items, prompting her to laugh about her strict rule‑following and battery‑packing habits.  She used the experience to highlight her new Roku Channel series that chronicles her solo travels to Morocco, Spain and Mexico, noting that she often checks multiple bags and follows a “bring it all” policy.  The article also references related PEOPLE pieces, including Southwest Airlines’ new lithium‑battery restrictions, Nicole Byer’s travel hacks, and a retrospective on the Black‑ish cast’s career.  Together, the pieces paint a picture of celebrity travel culture and evolving airline safety measures.
props.title: Tracee Ellis Ross Reveals TSA Pulled a 'Private' Rechargeable Item Out of Her Bag at Security

props.summary: Tracee Ellis Ross recounted an awkward TSA screening on the August 15 episode of Jimmy Kimmel Live, when agents opened her carry‑on and found a rechargeable bedside item she had kept in line with airline rules. She used the moment to promote her new Roku Channel series, Solo Traveling, and shared how her solo‑traveling reputation has grown into a dedicated following. The article also highlights Southwest Airlines’ May 28 restriction on portable batteries in bags and includes guest host Nicole Byer’s own airport mishaps and travel‑packing tips.
props.title: Tracee Ellis Ross Reveals TSA Pulled a 'Private' Rechargeable Item Out of Her Bag at Security

props.summary: OpenAI’s ChatGPT mobile app earns $2.91 per install and has generated $1.35 billion in revenue this year, far surpassing rivals such as Grok and Claude. With roughly 690 million global downloads and an average of 45 million monthly downloads, the app has seen a 180 % jump in usage compared to the previous year. The data fuel a dispute between Elon Musk’s xAI and OpenAI over alleged Apple App Store ranking favoritism. Meanwhile, OpenAI announced GPT‑5, promising “PhD‑level expert” capabilities across all fields.
props.title: ChatGPT app makes $2 billion, earns $2.91 per install: report

props.summary: Former Liberty University employee Erika Woolfolk has sued the Christian university, claiming she was fired for cooperating with a federal investigation into the school’s handling of sexual assault cases and that she endured a hostile, racially discriminatory workplace with unequal pay. Liberty denies the allegations, saying her termination was for legitimate business reasons tied to Title IX investigations, and the suit follows a similar case by former investigator Peter Brake. The lawsuit comes amid a $16 million fine imposed by the Department of Education for widespread Title IX and Clery Act violations, and the university is under federal monitoring until 2026. Liberty also recently settled a lawsuit with former president Jerry Falwell Jr. for a similar claim of retaliation, while the federal probe has uncovered a culture of fear that discouraged survivors from reporting incidents.
props.title: Liberty University faces second lawsuit accusing it of mishandling sexual assault cases

props.summary: North Chicago is tightening its video‑gaming regulations as it prepares to remediate the 41‑acre Sheridan Crossing site, aiming to shift the area’s economic focus from gambling to mixed residential and commercial development. The city will no longer issue new gaming licenses to businesses whose primary revenue comes from gaming or to certain venues such as liquor stores and gas stations, while existing licenses can be retained only by the original owners. The mayor expects the loss of gaming income to be offset by increased property‑tax revenue from future development, and the council will still need to approve any new license on a case‑by‑case basis.
props.title: North Chicago tightening reins on gaming licenses, after city makes changes in its code

props.summary: Washington DC Attorney General Brian Schwalb filed a lawsuit to block President Trump’s federal takeover of the city’s Metropolitan Police Department, arguing that the appointment of DEA Administrator Terry Cole as emergency police commissioner exceeds the limited authority granted under the District of Columbia Home Rule Act. Trump invoked Section 740 to deploy the National Guard and appoint Attorney General Pam Bondi as his stand‑in, citing rampant crime and homelessness. The suit seeks to restore command to Mayor Muriel Bowser and Police Chief Pamela Smith, who has publicly shown uncertainty about the new chain of command. A linked article from Modernity News highlights Smith’s confusion over the term “chain of command” amid the federal intervention, underscoring the administrative turmoil in DC policing.
props.title: DC Attorney General Sues Over Trump's 'Hostile Takeover'

props.summary: The post-launch review finds the app’s experience inconsistent and somewhat unfinished, with basic inquiries and personalized recommendations falling short. Users noted that the app could determine their zip code but failed to tailor suggestions to that area, and the Discover feed displayed irrelevant, often edgy images that may not suit all audiences. Additionally, the service’s presence on WhatsApp, Messenger, and Instagram remains disconnected, preventing seamless data sharing and undermining its personalization goals. Overall, the app shows promise but requires significant refinement to deliver a cohesive, user‑centric experience.
props.title: Meta’s Consumer AI App Struggles

props.summary: Reese Witherspoon shares a candid Instagram carousel about juggling her Hollywood career and motherhood, featuring photos of her three children over the years. She describes long work hours, late nights, and the challenge of balancing set demands with family life, yet emphasizes the perspective and joy her kids bring. Witherspoon concludes that despite the difficulties, being a mother has helped her focus on what truly matters and provides a meaningful counterbalance to her professional commitments.
props.title: Reese Witherspoon says she was 'deliriously tired' raising kids in Hollywood: 'I'd cry working 14 to 17 hours'

props.summary: The Razer Viper V2 Pro is a lightweight, minimalist gaming mouse that cuts 20% of the weight of its predecessor by removing grips, side buttons, and RGB lighting, aiming to give esports players speed and control. It boasts a 25% faster connection, up to 80 hours of battery life, and a $50 discount at Newegg, making it a compelling option for gamers on a budget. Reviewers have praised its design changes as a perfect match for competitive play, awarding it an "Excellent" rating. The article highlights the mouse’s advantages in games like Overwatch 2 and Valorant and encourages readers to check out additional computer mouse deals.
props.title: Heavy Savings, Light Mouse: 33% Off Razer Viper V2 Pro Gaming Mouse

props.summary: The article lambasts the finale of "And Just Like That…" for its gratuitous toilet scene, arguing it tarnishes the legacy of "Sex and the City" and signals a decline in the show’s quality and relevance. Fans and critics alike criticize the series’ shift toward forced diversity and shallow plotlines, citing the clogged‑toilet moment as emblematic of its broader failings. The piece also briefly touches on unrelated controversies—Jussie Smollett’s hoax, Howard Stern’s potential retirement, and an AI interview with a Parkland victim—to illustrate a media landscape rife with sensationalism and ethical concerns. Overall, the article portrays the show’s ending as a disappointing and unsexy conclusion to a once‑iconic franchise.
props.title: Even the most devoted ‘Sex and the City’ fans were disgusted and disappointed by ‘And Just Like That’ — the Fyre Festival of TV shows

props.summary: The IRS issued new rules tightening the definition of "beginning of construction" for wind and solar projects, eliminating the 5% safe harbor that previously allowed developers to claim tax credits after early equipment purchases. This change, combined with President Trump's bill that phases out tax credits for projects not started within 12 months, threatens the viability of many renewable energy developments. The safe harbor remains for rooftop and smaller solar installations, but large wind and solar farms face stricter qualification requirements.
props.title: New I.R.S. Rules for Large Wind and Solar Projects Released

props.summary: The Social Security Administration announced that it will add 13 new diseases and conditions to its Compassionate Allowances list, expanding the expedited benefits process to roughly 300 serious conditions. Since the program began in 2008, more than 1.1 million people with severe disabilities have received faster approvals. The update is part of the SSA’s effort to make disability determinations more responsive, though critics note that broader cuts to Social Security staff and related programs may undermine these gains. The article also briefly mentions a rare atmospheric‑river rain event in Oregon, a tuberculosis case at a Santa Paula elementary school, and unrelated coverage of a Grateful Dead‑themed Oregon football game, but these are not directly related to the SSA news.
props.title: Faster Social Security disability claims now cover 300 serious conditions

props.summary: Sean Kingston, the 35-year-old singer known for his hit song "Beautiful Girls" and "Eenie Meenie," has been sentenced to three and a half years in prison for his involvement in a months-long scheme that defrauded luxury goods businesses of more than $1 million. The sentence comes after a Florida court convicted Kingston and his mother, Janice Turner, of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and four counts of wire fraud each. Kingston's attorney, Zeljka Bozanic, expressed satisfaction that the court opted for a shorter prison sentence and stated that most of the restitution in this case was paid back before these charges were brought. Prosecutors accused Kingston and Turner of swindling over $480,000 worth of jewelry from one person and, from others, a Cadillac Escalade worth nearly $160,000 and furniture costing upwards of $86,500.
props.title: Sean Kingston is sentenced to 3½ years in prison after mom got 5 years for fraud scheme

props.summary: September WTI crude and gasoline futures fell as traders reacted to the Trump‑Putin summit, with President Trump threatening higher tariffs on Russian oil if no ceasefire is reached, while progress could ease sanctions.  Oil supply outlooks from the IEA and EIA now project record global surpluses through 2026, and US shale output is expected to decline for the first time since 2021, adding to supply pressure.  OPEC+ has announced a significant production increase for September, and US crude inventories rose to a two‑month high, though tanker‑stored oil fell 5% from the previous week.  Active US oil rigs remain near a 3.75‑year low, reflecting reduced drilling activity amid low prices.
props.title: Crude Oil Closes Lower Ahead of Trump-Putin Summit

props.summary: Appfigures’ latest analysis shows ChatGPT’s mobile app has generated $2 billion in global consumer spending since its May 2023 launch, a 673 % year‑over‑year jump and 53 times the revenue of its nearest rival, Grok. The app has been downloaded 318 million times this year, with India leading installs (13.7 %) and the U.S. driving nearly 40 % of revenue at an average $10 per download. ChatGPT also tops competitors in lifetime revenue per install ($2.91 vs. Claude’s $2.55, Grok’s $0.75, Copilot’s $0.27), while Grok’s later mobile launch explains its lower earnings. Elon Musk’s recent accusations that Apple unfairly promotes ChatGPT were quickly refuted, and the data underscores the app’s dominance in the App Store charts.
props.title: Appfigures: ChatGPT app sees a 673% increase in global revenue

props.summary: Senator Josh Hawley has demanded that Meta hand over documents related to its AI chatbot policies that allegedly allowed romantic and sensual exchanges with minors, prompting a congressional investigation and Meta's claim that the examples were erroneous. Hawley’s campaign has also faced a cease‑and‑desist from Politico over the sale of a Jan. 6 photo of him raising a fist, which Hawley defends as fair use. The article recounts Hawley’s controversial role in the Capitol riot, his criticism from former allies, and his lone Republican vote against the COVID‑19 Hate Crimes Act, which President Biden signed to address rising anti‑Asian violence. The piece concludes with a brief overview of the Act’s provisions and bipartisan support for combating hate crimes amid the pandemic.
props.title: Sen. Hawley says he'll investigate Meta's 'sensual' child chatbot policies

props.summary: The article explains that while generative AI model costs are falling, the true expense for enterprises lies in hidden infrastructure, integration, compliance, and ongoing operations, often outweighing token fees. It highlights that self‑hosting or embedded AI can cut costs and that many businesses are adopting AI incrementally to avoid falling behind. The piece also discusses how small and medium‑size firms are using AI to level the playing field, especially in accounting and customer service, and contrasts chatbots with more autonomous AI agents. Finally, a CFO survey shows that strategic, high‑impact AI deployments yield higher ROI, but many firms still face integration and executive‑support challenges.
props.title: Enterprises Confront the Real Price Tag of AI Deployment

props.summary: Plex Media Server users running versions 1.41.7.x through 1.42.0.x are urged to update immediately after the company released a patch for a serious, undisclosed vulnerability discovered via its bug‑bounty program. The fix, available in version 1.42.1.10060, has not yet been assigned a CVE ID and Plex has withheld technical details to prevent exploitation. The company’s unusual step of emailing affected customers underscores the severity, echoing past incidents such as the 2020 RCE flaw (CVE‑2020‑5741) that was actively exploited. Users should download the update from the Plex server or official download page as soon as possible.
props.title: Update Your Plex Server Now to Fix This Security Vulnerability

props.summary: A 46‑year‑old hiker, Ryan Wardwell, was rescued by helicopter after spending two days trapped behind the Seven Teacups waterfalls in Sequoia National Forest. He had fallen off his rappel lines and become stuck in a dark cave beneath the waterfall, where he could not escape or dry out. Rescue teams located him with a drone, lowered a helicopter crew member into the cave, and hoisted both men to safety, treating Wardwell for minor injuries and dehydration. The incident highlights the dangers of white‑water canyoneering and urges hikers to assess their experience and equipment before venturing into such environments.
props.title: Friends Left Note on Hiker’s Car in Case He Didn’t Return from Waterfall. He Was Found Trapped 2 Days Later

props.summary: A 46‑year‑old California hiker, Ryan Wardwell, was rescued after two days trapped behind the Seven Teacups waterfalls, with rescuers using a drone and helicopter to extract him from a dark cave. Separately, a 7‑year‑old boy in Florida sustained permanent injuries when a drone from a holiday show struck him, leading to a lawsuit against the city of Orlando and other parties. In Colorado, 23‑year‑old Blake Kieckhafer disappeared after a rideshare drop at Rocky Mountain National Park, with no updates since his last sighting on August 7 and authorities urging tips.
props.title: Friends Left Note on Hiker’s Car in Case He Didn’t Return from Waterfall. He Was Found Trapped 2 Days Later

props.summary: The author, adopted after her birth mother Maurine Hunsaker was murdered by Ralph Menzies in 1986, recounts the long‑term trauma of losing her parents and the emotional journey of learning her identity and connecting with half‑siblings. She explains how the murder has shaped her sense of self, contributed to anxiety and depression, and left her with a lingering emptiness. Despite the severity of Menzies’ crime, she opposes the death penalty, arguing that execution would perpetuate violence, cause further suffering, and that clemency would better serve healing and compassion. She urges the Utah Board of Pardons and Parole to commute Menzies’ sentence to incarceration, emphasizing that true closure should focus on rehabilitation rather than retribution.
props.title: Death by incarceration is enough

props.summary: Sophie Turner recalled an awkward encounter at a 2014 San Diego Comic‑Con party that may have caused a celebrity couple to call off their engagement. While waving to an actor she didn’t know, a famous actress later confronted her, accusing her of flirting with her fiancé. Turner joked that her simple wave might have had unintended consequences, and the incident was discussed on Seth Meyers’ Late Night.
props.title: Sophie Turner recalls accidentally ending celebrity couple's engagement at San Diego Comic-Con party

props.summary: Via Transportation’s IPO filing outlines a unified cloud‑based stack that merges trip planning, real‑time dispatch, eligibility checks and fare payments, positioning the company as a programmable transit platform. It cites an $82 billion serviceable market in North America and Western Europe, with revenue growing from $248.9 million in 2023 to $337.6 million in 2024 and 100% platform revenue in 2025. The platform enables agencies to consolidate disparate systems, cutting costs (e.g., a Florida agency saw a 50% drop in cost‑per‑ride) while offering dynamic pricing, subsidies and digital wallet payments. The filing notes that 14% of people use travel apps weekly, and Citymapper serves as the consumer front‑door for the service. Overall, the narrative frames modern transit as a software‑driven, data‑rich ecosystem that boosts efficiency, equity and rider experience.
props.title: Via Bets on Connected Transit as It Heads to IPO

props.summary: Sony’s WH‑1000XM6 headphones build on an eight‑year lineage of industry‑leading ANC, featuring a new QN3 processor that is seven times faster than the XM5’s and 12 microphones for superior noise cancellation. The 30‑mm drivers with a perforated voice coil and soft‑edge dome improve bass and high‑frequency detail, while the balanced out‑of‑the‑box sound can be fine‑tuned via the Sound Connect app, DSEE Extreme, and 360 Reality Audio. The model retains Sony’s fold‑away design and a robust carry case, making it travel‑friendly. TechRadar’s broader headphone guide notes that the XM6 tops the ANC category, though other premium options like the Bowers & Wilkins Px7 S3 offer stronger sound quality and the Sony XM4 remains a value‑oriented alternative.
props.title: Immersive music with no interruptions: the Sony WH-1000XM6 headphones set a new bar for active noise cancellation

props.summary: The article covers the stalled contract negotiations between the Dallas Cowboys and star pass rusher Micah Parsons, who requested a trade on August 1 and has remained largely silent. Chiefs All‑Pro Chris Jones expresses confidence that Parsons will stay in Dallas, noting mutual frustration but optimism that a deal will be reached. Cowboys owner Jerry Jones explains that talks have not restarted, emphasizes the importance of keeping Parsons on the field during training camp, and highlights the team's broader contract strategy. The piece also details training‑camp developments, player reactions, and the Cowboys’ handling of other contract situations. Overall, it paints a picture of a tense but potentially resolvable negotiation amid a busy preseason.
props.title: Chiefs’ Chris Jones on Micah Parsons saga: ‘I think Jerry Jones will get it worked out’

props.summary: Gemini Space Station, Inc., a global crypto platform founded by the Winklevoss twins, has filed a Form S-1 with the SEC to pursue an initial public offering of its Class A common stock, which will be listed on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the ticker "GEMI." The offering details, including share count and price range, remain undetermined and are subject to market conditions, with Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, and Cantor among the lead bookrunners. A preliminary prospectus will be available through the bookrunners once the registration becomes effective, and the company emphasizes that the filing does not constitute an offer to sell securities until the registration is effective.
props.title: Gemini Files Registration Statement with SEC for Proposed Initial Public Offering

props.summary: Galvanize Therapeutics has enrolled its first patient in the PROPEL Registry, a multicenter observational study to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of its Aliya Pulsed Electric Field (PEF) ablation system for soft tissue lesions in organs such as lung and liver. The Aliya PEF system uses short, high‑voltage electrical pulses to ablate tumors without damaging surrounding structures, preserving extracellular matrix and potentially stimulating immune responses. The registry will enroll up to 1,000 patients across 50 U.S. centers, following them for up to 24 months to capture procedural data, peri‑operative outcomes, and radiographic responses. By systematically collecting real‑world evidence, Galvanize aims to inform evidence‑based integration of its PEF technology into clinical care pathways and expand treatment options for patients with complex or previously irradiated lesions.
props.title: Galvanize Announces First Patient Enrolled in the PROPEL Registry Evaluating Aliya® Pulsed Electric Field Ablation for Soft Tissue Lesions

props.summary: The article advertises The Aerospace Forum, a subscription‑based aerospace, defense and airline research service on Seeking Alpha that offers reports, data and an in‑house analytics platform called evoX. It notes the growing interest in commercial lunar exploration, mentioning that only a few companies—including Firefly Aerospace—have successfully landed on the Moon. The piece also includes standard disclosures that the author holds no positions in the companies discussed and receives no compensation beyond Seeking Alpha. The overall focus is on promoting the research service and its data‑driven investment insights.
props.title: Firefly Aerospace: The Space Stock You Should Not Buy (NASDAQ:FLY)

props.summary: Ryght AI has partnered with CRO Biorasi to integrate its AI‑powered platform of digital twins for clinical research sites, offering sponsors real‑time, data‑driven site selection, feasibility, and enrollment forecasting. The collaboration promises to cut feasibility timelines from months to under three weeks, improve enrollment accuracy, reduce cost overruns, and accelerate study startup across dermatology, oncology, neurology, and nephrology. By automating feasibility workflows and providing continuously updated site profiles, the partnership aims to transform trial planning from guesswork into precise, AI‑guided decision making.
props.title: Ryght AI Partners with Global CRO Biorasi to Deliver AI-Powered Feasibility Solutions to Biotech and Biopharma Sponsors

props.summary: The article reports the 2026 Princeton Review Best Colleges rankings, noting Thomas Aquinas College as the most conservative and Reed College as the most liberal, and explains the survey‑based methodology behind the 50 category lists. It also recounts the dramatic story of Helen Green, who unexpectedly gave birth to a baby in a Toronto hotel while on vacation, highlighting the ensuing bureaucratic challenges and financial costs. Additionally, the piece includes excerpts from a Dear Abby column addressing family dynamics and pet‑related hospitality concerns, and a discussion of the rising popularity of the graysexual identity among Gen Z, detailing its definition, community support, and cultural context.
props.title: The most conservative college in the US is just a short drive from lefty LA — and has just 372 students

props.summary: Five envelopes containing boric acid and menacing notes were found in the mailroom of 26 Federal Plaza, the Manhattan ICE field office, prompting a swift evacuation and a joint response by FDNY, NYPD, FBI and federal partners.  The letters threatened ICE employees with “karma” and referenced an Anthrax song, but preliminary tests confirmed no hazardous toxins were present.  ICE officials thanked responders and reiterated their commitment to national security while the FBI’s Quantico lab continues the investigation.  The incident follows a federal judge’s order to improve conditions at the ICE holding facility, including a ban on toothbrushes, amid ongoing scrutiny of the agency’s detention practices.
props.title: White-powder envelope sent to NYC ICE office said it was delivering ‘karma’ for migrants

props.summary: Fundamental Administrative Services LLC announced a data security event that exposed personal information of residents in long‑term care facilities, with an unauthorized actor copying files between October 27, 2024, and January 13, 2025. The compromised data could include names, SSNs, driver’s license numbers, financial account details, medical and insurance information, and dates of birth. Affected individuals are being notified by letter and can obtain further details via a toll‑free line or the company’s website, which also offers guidance on protecting against identity theft. The company has tightened security measures and is reviewing policies to prevent future incidents.
props.title: Fundamental Administrative Services, LLC Provides Notice of Data Security Event

props.summary: Air Canada and Air Canada Rouge flight attendants, represented by the Canadian Union of Public Employees, have issued a 72‑hour strike notice and are set to picket, prompting the airline to cancel flights in anticipation of a full grounding. The attendants demand pay for ground work before takeoff, a 50‑100% increase in boarding pay, and a one‑percentage‑point raise in annual wages. Management, led by Tom Fitzgerald, urges a conciliatory approach, warning that a three‑day strike could cost the airline $300 million in EBITDA and that investors are growing frustrated with the current strategy. Fitzgerald maintains that resolving the dispute will secure labor peace, improve public perception, and position the company well for future growth.
props.title: Air Canada risks 'pyrrhic victory' in sending flight attendants to the picket lines, says TD analyst

props.summary: SpaceX plans to launch its Starship megarocket on August 24 for its 10th test flight after a series of fiery explosions that damaged the vehicle and caused debris to fall over the Caribbean. The 403‑foot rocket, designed to be fully reusable, has suffered multiple upper‑stage failures, including a fuel‑leak‑induced loss of control in May and a ground‑test blast in June. Elon Musk insists the vehicle will soon carry uncrewed missions to Mars, while the company faces criticism from Mexican officials over debris and environmental impacts. The U.S. aviation regulator has approved an increase in annual launches from five to 25, signaling continued testing despite setbacks.
props.title: After Repeated Explosions, New Test For Musk's Megarocket

props.summary: Health officials in Wyoming are warning that up to 500 visitors to bat‑infested cabins at Grand Teton National Park may have been exposed to rabies, after bats were found in several cabins. None of the tested bats tested positive, but officials are erring on the side of caution and recommending prophylactic shots for people who may have had contact with bats, especially deep sleepers and young children. The cabins have been closed since July 27 and there are no plans to exterminate the bats, though measures are in place to prevent re‑entry. The alert is being sent to residents of 38 states and seven countries through health agencies and the CDC. The situation underscores the importance of rapid post‑exposure treatment to prevent the almost always fatal rabies virus in humans.
props.title: Hundreds may have been exposed to rabies at bat-infested cabins at Grand Teton National Park

props.summary: Nanofilm Technologies International has swung from a S$3.74 m loss in H1 2024 to a S$1.61 m profit, with a 1.5% margin and EPS of S$0.002, driven by higher revenue and a strong balance sheet (debt‑to‑equity 21.2%, interest coverage 20.1x). Forecasts project earnings growth of 17.7% and revenue growth of 8.6% per year, with a modest 4.8% return on equity in three years, while the company’s dividend has been adjusted to SGD 0.0033. Singapore’s market remains flat over the last week, with the utilities sector falling 16% but the overall market up 26% year‑to‑date; key contributors include telecom, energy, and financials. A list of 21 US stocks is highlighted as expected to yield over 6% next year, and the article notes that Singapore’s market valuation has risen to a P/E of 13.9x as of 15 Aug 2025.
props.title: Nanofilm Technologies International First Half 2025 Earnings: EPS: S$0.002 (vs S$0.006 loss in 1H 2024)

props.summary: The article explains how IBD rates stocks across 33 industry sectors using a composite score that combines EPS growth, relative strength, industry group strength, SMR (sales, profit, ROE), and accumulation/distribution metrics. Each rating ranges from 1 to 99 or A–E, with higher numbers indicating stronger performance. The piece also details visual cues such as color-coded stock names, 52‑week high indicators, and volume change highlights to help investors quickly identify top performers.
props.title: IBD Smart NYSE + Nasdaq Tables -- Aug 15, 2025

props.summary: Air Canada flight attendants, represented by the Canadian Union of Public Employees, have issued a 72‑hour strike notice and are set to picket over unpaid ground work and pay issues. Company management, as noted by Tom Fitzgerald, is urged to offer a 50‑100% increase in boarding pay and a modest annual raise to secure labour peace and avoid a costly strike. Fitzgerald warns that each day of stoppage could cost the airline $75 million EBITDA, totaling $300 million over a three‑day strike, and notes investor frustration with management’s approach. He believes that resolving the dispute will position the airline well for future growth post‑COVID.
props.title: Air Canada risks 'pyrrhic victory' in sending flight attendants to the picket lines, says TD analyst

props.summary: A police report on the August 5 crash in Anderson, involving a stolen 2006 Ford F250, found no clear driver among its three occupants. The vehicle, pursued by Alexandria officers for suspected drunken and reckless driving, was traveling the wrong way at high speed, crashed into two buildings, and overturned, killing 20‑year‑old Preston Jett and 17‑year‑old Landon Shaffer while 16‑year‑old Dalton Jett survived the crash. The chase ended about 12 miles from its start, and investigators remain uncertain who was driving at the time of the collision.
props.title: More details emerge in fatal crash in Anderson

props.summary: A federal judge issued a preliminary injunction blocking the FTC’s civil investigative demand against Media Matters, ruling that the agency’s actions were likely retaliatory and violated the First Amendment. The demand, sent by FTC Chair Andrew Ferguson, sought information on Media Matters’ contacts with advertising groups after the watchdog published a 2023 piece on antisemitic posts next to ads on Elon Musk’s X. The judge noted that the demand had already deterred Media Matters from reporting on the FTC, Musk, and the agency’s leadership, and that the timing and comments by Ferguson suggested pretext. Media Matters, already strained by legal costs and staff layoffs, has considered shutting down, underscoring the broader impact of the investigation on press freedom.
props.title: Judge Rules FTC Investigation Of Media Matters Violates First Amendment

props.summary: Former NBC host Chuck Todd accused President Biden of sabotaging the Democratic Party by staying in the 2024 race, claiming Biden’s inner circle deliberately scheduled a disastrous debate to expose his cognitive decline and force a withdrawal. Todd argues that Biden’s portrayal as a devoted family man was a myth and that the party’s failure to act earlier allowed Donald Trump to regain the presidency, making Biden’s legacy a ‘40‑year bill of goods.’ He further contends that Biden’s withdrawal and endorsement of Kamala Harris damaged the party’s credibility, while highlighting Trump’s historic comeback as a rare political reversal. The piece also recounts Biden’s 2024 exit, the ensuing Democratic turmoil, and Trump’s re‑election, framing the debate as a pivotal moment in American politics.
props.title: Chuck Todd says Biden's presidency was so 'weak and ineffective' it made people go back to Trump

props.summary: Lawrence Fuller, a 30‑year veteran of Wall Street, founded Fuller Asset Management and now runs the Focused Growth portfolio on Dub, the first regulator‑approved copy‑trading platform in the U.S. He promotes his strategies via Substack and other channels, emphasizing that the information is educational and not a solicitation. Fuller’s firm is a state‑registered investment adviser, and the article disclaims any material conflicts or positions in the companies discussed.
props.title: Inflation Revival – Tariffs Start Hitting Consumers Directly Today

props.summary: President Trump met Russian President Vladimir Putin in Anchorage, Alaska, for a three‑hour discussion that he described as a “listening exercise” and claimed made “great progress” toward ending Russia’s war in Ukraine, though no concrete terms were disclosed.  Trump said he would call Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and European allies to discuss any potential agreements, emphasizing that a deal would only come if all parties agreed.  Russian demands reportedly include recognition of Donetsk and Luhansk as Russian territory, a freeze of front lines, and Ukraine’s refusal to join NATO, while Ukraine insists on security guarantees and a final peace deal that protects its sovereignty.  The summit was seen by U.S. officials as a chance to gauge Putin’s willingness to negotiate, with no immediate outcomes expected and the meeting positioned as a precursor to a possible trilateral summit involving Zelensky.  Media coverage highlighted the lack of detail, the political stakes for Trump’s 2024 campaign, and the broader international debate over the feasibility of a cease‑fire under Moscow’s conditions.
props.title: Trump claims ‘great progress’ in Putin meeting — but holds details close pending calls to Zelensky, European allies

props.summary: Donald Trump claimed that Chinese President Xi Jinping told him he would not pursue Taiwan as long as Trump remained U.S. president, a statement made during a Fox News interview on his way to a summit with Russian leader Vladimir Putin. The remark underscores the U.S. policy of strategic ambiguity toward Taiwan, which relies on the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act to provide defensive resources without an explicit military guarantee. Trump’s comment follows his earlier suggestion that Taiwan should pay for its own defense. The U.S. has historically avoided direct intervention while maintaining a deterrent stance against Chinese military action on the island.
props.title: Trump says he believes Xi won't act on Taiwan

props.summary: The article laments the finale of the Sex and the City reboot “And Just Like That,” focusing on a gratuitous toilet‑overflow scene that angered fans and critics, and arguing that the show’s attempt to modernize with “woke” characters and plotlines has ruined its legacy. It recounts how the episode’s ending—showing a clogged toilet and a lonely Carrie Bradshaw—felt like a betrayal to longtime viewers, who expected a more uplifting conclusion. The piece also briefly touches on unrelated controversies, such as Jussie Smollett’s hoax, Howard Stern’s declining relevance, and an AI‑based interview with a Parkland victim, to illustrate broader cultural missteps. Overall, the author portrays the series as having lost its original charm and ending on a low note that many fans find insulting.
props.title: Even the most devoted ‘Sex and the City’ fans were disgusted and disappointed by ‘And Just Like That’ — the Fyre Festival of TV shows

props.summary: The U.S. Air Force has issued new guidance that automatically separates transgender service members with a diagnosis of gender dysphoria, denying them early retirement benefits and revoking previously approved separations. The policy removes the possibility of impartial board hearings, prohibits recording proceedings, and treats the diagnosis as the sole basis for separation, raising legal concerns about due process. Transgender troops and their advocates argue the change undermines fairness, equates identity with performance, and could set a precedent for other branches. The move follows a Supreme Court decision that allowed a Trump-era ban on transgender service members to take effect while lawsuits continue to challenge the policy.
props.title: New Air Force policy denies transgender troops hearings before they're discharged

props.summary: First Trust Canada announced the reset of the upside cap and the start of a new Target Outcome Period for the First Trust Vest U.S. Equity Buffer ETF – AUG (AUGB.F), aligning it with current market conditions. The fund aims to deliver returns that mirror the SPDR® S&P 500® ETF Trust (SPY) up to the capped level while offering a buffer against SPY losses, though units purchased after the first day may have different return potential. Portfolio managers Karan Sood and Trevor Lack oversee the strategy, and First Trust Canada serves as trustee, manager, and promoter of the ETF.
props.title: First Trust Portfolios Canada Announces Cap, Buffer and Dates of August Buffer ETF

props.summary: Gemini Space Station Inc. plans to list on Nasdaq under GEMI, but its S‑1 shows widening losses: a $158.5 million net loss on $142.2 million revenue in 2024 and a $282.5 million loss on $67.9 million revenue in the first half of 2025. The article highlights a surge in crypto IPO activity, noting Circle’s $1.1 billion offering that saw its shares jump 168% on debut and a market cap of $16.7 billion, and Bullish’s $1.1 billion IPO that more than doubled its price. These strong first‑day performances reflect growing investor appetite for crypto and stablecoin companies amid a more favorable regulatory environment. The piece also mentions other upcoming IPOs such as Omada Health and Chime, underscoring a broader trend of crypto firms turning to public markets as conditions improve.
props.title: Winklevoss twins' crypto company Gemini files for IPO
